entry.title: Combined summary - Proposal: Bundled payments
entry.summary: Thomas Voegtlin, the CEO of Electrum Technologies GmbH, has proposed an extension to BOLT-11 that includes two bundled payments with distinct preimages and amounts. This change is aimed at services that require prepayment of a mining fee for a non-custodian exchange such as submarine swaps and JIT channels. Implementing this proposal would level the field in terms of competition between lightning service providers. The semantics of bundled payments will be such that the BOLT-11 invoice contains two preimages and two amounts: prepayment and main payment. The receiver should wait until all the HTLCs (Hash Time-Locked Contracts) of both payments have arrived before they fulfill the HTLCs of the pre-payment. If the main payment does not arrive, they should fail the pre-payment with a MPP (Multi-Path Payments) timeout. Once the HTLCs of both payments have arrived, the receiver fulfills the HTLCs of the pre-payment, and they broadcast their on-chain transaction. However, some concerns have been raised regarding the implementation of this proposal, including the need for senders to be aware of the new fields and the potential difficulty of updating all existing software used by senders. Matt Corallo suggests working towards specifying some "standard" way of doing swaps, and why it shouldn't be built on OMs so you can do it more privately. Bastien Teinturier also suggests that extending Bolt 12 makes more sense than updating Bolt 11.Regarding Thomas's question about the distinction between splice-out and submarine swaps, Matt said that submarine swaps make it possible to add receiving capacity to a channel. Thomas believes that ACINQ would benefit from this because it would make it possible for them to make their pay-to-open service fully non-custodian. The decision to make this feature required or optional remains with the service provider. Thomas suggests that two major implementations have an incentive to support this proposal - Lightning Labs could potentially offer their Loop service to non-LND users, and ACINQ would be able to open channels to Phoenix users without requesting the preimage first. Ultimately, the decision to make this feature required or optional remains with the service provider. Overall, Bolt 12 seems more reasonable to include this new feature, since all implementations are actively working on it. However, Thomas Voegtlin mentions that they will implement BOLT-12 support in Electrum in the coming months, and believes that if the proposed feature was adopted in BOLT-11, it could be deployed much faster than BOLT-12. Nonetheless, Matt Corallo disagrees with this, stating that a new BOLT-11 extension has to start from 0 with zero implementations today and having to convince people to actually care enough to implement it.
